geeklist.title: The Australian Mid Year Math Trade 2012
geeklist.description:
Due to popular demand, here is the next Aussie math trade just in time for BorderCon12
This Math Trade is brought to you by co-op of
[floatleft][username=Friendless][/floatleft][floatleft][username=prd1982][/floatleft][floatleft][username=batcut][/floatleft][floatleft][username=Amiguero][/floatleft][clear]
Cash option as per the previous Math Trades is available.
The boring bit:
By posting an item to this list you are agreeing that you can and will mail it anywhere in Australia at your expense. If it looks like that's going to cost a lot, make sure you don't trade it for something crap.
There will be [b]NO removal of entries possible[/b] as this made it difficult for some people to track items.
More details about the cash bids look here
http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/483458/australian-ultimate-trade-subscription-thread-and
[b][size=18]Specific Rules:[/size][/b]
:star: This trade is open to Australian BGGers only.
:star: This trade is open to board games, expansions, card games, game accessories, RPG, video games and the like. Please don't add anything else. If you intend to allow a game to be exchanged for cash (i.e. you're selling), please include the amount you will accept for it in the price. You may consider compare current market prices (ebay, BGG, local shop)
:star: In ALL cases, [b]SENDER PAYS SHIPPING[/b]. Even if you're selling a game for cash, [b]SENDER PAYS SHIPPING[/b]. Even to Perth or Townsville or Hobart. So, make sure you set your price high enough that you would be happy to pay shipping to anywhere else in Australia out of that money.
:star: Consider the Australian Post option of flat-rate box previously suggested. More details [url=http://auspost.ebay.com.au/flat-rate-box?clk_rvr_id=288654101739]here[/url].
:star: There is an expectation for items included in the math trade to remain as part of the math trade until the closing date. If your intention is to sell an item there are other alternatives in BGG to do so. If an item is not longer available for whatever reason, please indicate so with big letters.
[b]Note[/b]: BGG runs a marketplace where sellers pay 3% commission to BGG, and I recommend that this should apply here as well. As Aldie's debt-collectors don't get over this way very much, I suggest that sellers make a donation of that 3% using the standard BGG donation system.
:star: Traders will not be required to add cash items to the geeklist - that will be handled in the want lists. In the case that a buyer offers more than a seller is asking, the buyer will pay the seller's price. Sorry sellers, this is not an auction, this is a maths trade, and you only get as much as you ask for.
:star: Australian BGGers can participate even without submitting an item to the trade with the cash option by submitting want list as indicated below.
[b]Limits:[/b]
Feel free to put as many items on the list as you want. Duplicates of items already on the list are okay. You can combine multiple games into one item (e.g. Alhambra plus expansions).
Describe the edition, language, and condition of the game. Pick a picture that represents the game you're offering if there are multiple versions. If necessary, take a picture of the game, upload it to your gallery, and use that image.
Feel free to use the rating suggested by petegs to describe your items:
[b]New in shrink[/b] - which means never opened. [b]Opened but unpunched[/b] - I've looked at the game but not punched counters yet or stickered blocks etc. [b]Opened and punched[/b] - Looked at, even punched counters etc but haven't played. [b]Opened and played[/b].
Count pieces to make sure the games are complete, and accurately list any components that are missing or damaged. Please look at your trade pile to make sure the game is really there.
In order to make your items more (or less) appealing, you may want to add one or more "sweeteners" to the item listing -- an expansion, a related game, or a completely unrelated item that you think will make it a more desirable package.
Items for which there is no BGG listing can be listed as Miscellaneous Game Accessory.
[b]Algorithm:[/b]
Trade lists will be found by TradeMaximizer using SCALED-PRIORITIES, ALLOW-DUMMIES, REQUIRE-COLONS and REQUIRE-USERNAMES switches. The actual code is a heavily modified version of Trade Maximiser 1.3a, modified to allow geeklist integration (as we've been using in Australia for a couple of years) and now the cash bids. The (Java) source code will be available to anyone who's interested.
[b]Deadlines:[/b]
Add items to the list by: [b][-]10pm Sunday 20th May 2012[/-][/b]. EST (SYD/CBR) Australian Time
Official item list posted by: [b][-]10pm Wednesday 23th May 2012[/-][/b]. EST (SYD/CBR) Australian Time
Want Lists Due By: [b][-]10pm Sunday 27th May 2012[/-][/b]. EST (SYD/CBR) Australian Time
[COLOR=#000099][b]Want list submission via GeekMail to[/b] [/COLOR]
[user=Friendless][/user]
Official Results Posted By: [b]6pm Wednesday 30 May 2012[/b]. EST (SYD/CBR) Australian Time
[COLOR=#CC0000][size=18]Math Trade Result:[/size][/COLOR]
[size=24][url=http://friendless.servegame.org/stats/result.html]HERE[/url][/size]
and
[size=24][geekurl=/article/9274457#9274457]HERE[/geekurl][/size]
There really is no leeway for that, as people may need to get their games to a willing 'games mule' attending BorderCon.
[i]Packing tips:[/i] - Make sure the game contents are secure [i]inside[/i]the game and won't shift around. - Place the game in a plastic bag to prevent water damage (in the event it is left out in the rain). - Make sure there's cushioning around all side of the game. - Use a proper box. (Auspost "ToughBags" won't prevent crushing.) - Make sure the box is properly taped up. - Make sure the address is clear and won't get torn off.
I suggest follow the recommendations above even if you are not posting your items and using a 'game mule'.
[b]Want List Format:[/b]
The official item list will be of a format something like: 0001-TWIXT 0002-BMOON 0003-PUERT 0004-TICHU
Want lists must be submitted in a format like
([i]your user name[/i]-batcut) 0001-TWIXT : 0004-TICHU 0002-BMOON
indicating that batcut, the person who put item 0001, a Twixt game, into the list would be willing to accept either item 0004, a Tichu game, or item 0002, Blue Moon, in trade for it. The order of listing is your order of preference, in case both trades are possible.
The order of wants is a tiebreaker only. The system will first try to maximise the number of trades, even if this means that you get your last preference. The order of your wants will only be considered if there are multiple ways to get the maximum trades. But, fear not! You will never get a game that is not on your want list.
If you put 5 games on this trade list, you will be submitting 5 different want lists.
You may also submit want lists for cash bids. In that case, you write something like this:
([i]your user name[/i]-batcut) $20 : 0004-TICHU 0002-BMOON
meaning that batcut has $20 and he'll pay it for either Tichu or Blue Moon. You could also write this:
([i]your user name[/i]-batcut) $10 : 0004-TICHU ([i]your user name[/i]-batcut) $20 : 0002-BMOON
meaning that batcut will pay $10 for Tichu and $20 for Blue Moon, so batcut could be up for $30 total. To ensure that you don't spend all of your beer money, you can add a spending limit just like this:
([i]your user name[/i]-batcut) LIMIT : $30
which means that no matter what happens, batcut won't win trades such that he has to spend more than $30. I'll tell you how that works. We run the trade algorithm, and inspect the results. If anyone has exceeded their spending limit, their highest-priced successful bid is removed and the algorithm is re-run. Continue until all spending limits are satisfied. If you don't specify a spending limit, the program infers a limit which is the highest amount you've been for any single item. That will be a rather conservative limit, but follows the maxim of no nasty surprises.
To sell a game, you can submit a trade list like this:
([i]your user name[/i]-batcut) 0001-TWIXT : 0004-TICHU 0002-BMOON $30
meaning that for Twixt batcut will accept Tichu, or Blue Moon, or $30 from anyone who's offering cash.
Finally, do not try to screw the system. The program will reject nonsense like this:
(batcut) $10: $20 (batcut) %CASH: $20 (batcut) $10: %CASH (batcut) $20: $10
and furthermore John reserves the right to change the program to reject anything else he sees as a scam and not an honest trade. Please post any questions in the Geeklist Comments below.
Detailed discussions about the math trade [geekurl=/thread/788003/aussie-mid-year-2012-math-trade-discussion-threa][COLOR=#0000FF][size=18]HERE[/size][/COLOR][/geekurl].
Finally, please let know others that the math trade is up and running.
geeklist.comment:
Are you guys going to trade some Legos?
:meeple:
[i]Already?[/i]:meeple:

[q="Leezer"]Are you guys going to trade some Legos?
:meeple:[/q]
Nope... but we might consider "lego" :)
1 lego brick, 2 lego brick's...
Not having a go at you Leezer, just at the difference between Australian English and American English.

[q="Ykikamucow"]Not having a go at you Leezer, just at the difference between Australian English and American English. [/q]
On that note, shouldn't we be calling this a Math[i]s[/i] Trade, rather than Math Trade? ;) :p

[q="Tegs"][q="Ykikamucow"]Not having a go at you Leezer, just at the difference between Australian English and American English. [/q]
On that note, shouldn't we be calling this a Math[i]s[/i] Trade, rather than Math Trade? ;) :p[/q]
A rose by any other name would smell as sweet - and does it really matter or is this simply pedantry?

[q="Tegs"]On that note, shouldn't we be calling this a Math[i]s[/i] Trade, rather than Math Trade? ;) :p[/q]
Yes! As a maths teacher I whole heartedly support this motion :)

[q="vanadamme"][q="Tegs"]On that note, shouldn't we be calling this a Math[i]s[/i] Trade, rather than Math Trade? ;) :p[/q]
Yes! As a maths teacher I whole heartedly support this motion :)[/q]
A serious question - why?
[b]I don't see any difference.[/b] If it is because Math is US jargon that is not in itself a reason. I embrace US spellings such as color and harbor as being more logical. At the time of Shakespeare doctor was spelt doctour but with time we have come to a more logical spelling that is consistent with common pronounciation.

[q="da pyrate"]A serious question - why?[/q]
For the same reason we don't swear allegiance to the president - this is not the U.S.

[q="da pyrate"][q="vanadamme"][q="Tegs"]On that note, shouldn't we be calling this a Math[i]s[/i] Trade, rather than Math Trade? ;) :p[/q]
Yes! As a maths teacher I whole heartedly support this motion :)[/q]
A serious question - why?
[b]I don't see any difference.[/b] If it is because Math is US jargon that is not in itself a reason. I embrace US spellings such as color and harbor as being more logical. At the time of Shakespeare doctor was spelt doctour but with time we have come to a more logical spelling that is consistent with common pronounciation.[/q]
You probably leave the 'me' off the end of programme too, right?

[q="da pyrate"] A serious question - why?
[b]I don't see any difference.[/b] If it is because Math is US jargon that is not in itself a reason. I embrace US spellings such as color and harbor as being more logical. At the time of Shakespeare doctor was spelt doctour but with time we have come to a more logical spelling that is consistent with common pronounciation.[/q]
Not to go terribly off topic but 'maths' is the accepted term in Australia. American spellings like 'color' and 'harbor' are technically acceptable here, they are just generally not used.
It's mostly personal preference, but I for one relish the few remaining parts of identity that we're allowed to hold on to without feeling a need to imitate other countries.
Furthermore, since when has logic ever had anything to do with the Australian/English language?

Note that the flat-rate boxes are still available as well: $6.50 for Bx1 (code 00069), $10.50 for Bx2 (code 00076) and $13.25 for the Bx4 (code 00090). Unless you already have some, you have to buy the box as well; and you have to pay online via Click-and-Send, then take it to a post office for lodgement. But $13.25 for 15kg to Perth from the east coast, including tracking, is pretty good too :D
Link is [url]http://auspost.ebay.com.au[/url] (the front page there now talks about smaller flat-rate satchels than James discusses above, namely $6.20 for 500g and $10.55 for 3kg, plus the satchels themselves), but once you register for Click-and-Send you can access the box info too.
Regards,
David.
More than happy for any real Aussie to organise the next [i]Maths[/i] Trade, so they don't pick on the non-native English speaker spelling. :yuk:

[q="da pyrate"]A serious question - why?[/q] Because we are Australians (visitors, residents and citizens) discussing a trade [i]in Australia[/i]. The word in Australian English is [i]Maths[/i]. If the language ever transforms to the extent that "Math" is predominant, then that is what will be used, naturally.
In the meantime, its use on this list is odd. It isn't that "Math" makes understanding difficult: it is simply out of place. Arguably we should champion our cultural differences too- not because Australian culture is superior* (!), but because [i]difference is interesting[/i], it adds depth and texture to life.
[size=7]* Although we play cricket and "they" play [i]baseball[/i].[/size]
I had a wonderfully quirky, passionate and intelligent maths lecturer who went nuts about math/maths (mathematics!). Ever since her, 'math' has always looked and sounded wrong.

Undeniably the word in Maths in Australian English, but I would be interested to learn the etymology of the phrase "Math Trade".
If the phrase was first coined in the US then one could argue that the "correct" usage is "Math Trade" and not "Maths Trade", respecting its origin.
I don't really care either way. Kudos to the organisers of the Australian Algorithm Trade for taking to time and energy to put this together again. Its always fun!

[q="jamesmckane"]Hey everyone, I just thought I'd link to a [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/789111/postage-information-for-australians-might-be-help]recent post of mine[/url] that may help those here having to post games. There is a new Australia Post satchel that I think I'll be using from now on to send games in the future:). [/q]
I obviously cannot speak for everyone James, but I would be very annoyed to have a game shipped to me in a satchel rather than a box, so that it is almost guaranteed to suffer some form of ding/dent damage.
As a trader I take a fair amount of time and effort to pack games to the best of my ability, and the pride I have in the knowledge that I have done the best I possibly can to get the game to the receiver in exactly the same condition it left is worth more than the dollar or two more it might cost to put in a box.

[q="ausminstrel"][q="jamesmckane"]Hey everyone, I just thought I'd link to a [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/789111/postage-information-for-australians-might-be-help]recent post of mine[/url] that may help those here having to post games. The point is valid and the satchel may not be appropriate for all games (depending on size) but there's no reason you can't box it and then chuck it in the satchel. Just think of the satchel as a reeeeally big postage stamp that covers the whole box.
Except that the box postage is [i]cheaper[/i] than the satchel postage, if you pre-pay via Click-and-Send :-)

[q="jamesmckane"][q="ausminstrel"][q="jamesmckane"]Hey everyone, I just thought I'd link to a [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/789111/postage-information-for-australians-might-be-help]recent post of mine[/url] that may help those here having to post games. There is a new Australia Post satchel that I think I'll be using from now on to send games in the future:). [/q]I obviously cannot speak for everyone James, but I would be very annoyed to have a game shipped to me in a satchel rather than a box, so that it is almost guaranteed to suffer some form of ding/dent damage.
As a trader I take a fair amount of time and effort to pack games to the best of my ability, and the pride I have in the knowledge that I have done the best I possibly can to get the game to the receiver in exactly the same condition it left is worth more than the dollar or two more it might cost to put in a box.[/q]O.k, it should go without saying that you shouldn't put the game in a satchel and post it off expecting it to arrive safe n' sound. But it's easy to get bubble wrap really cheap and get cardboard for free and wrap the game box in that, and then send it off in a satchel. You'll get cardboard for free from any grog shop and bubblewrap from Austraila Post or Officeworks for a couple of dollars and it'll be enough to wrap a few games. [/q]Just because you pack it with bubble wrap and "cardboard for free" does not mean that will reduce the possibility of crushing in transit. IMHO speaking from experience with these postpak boxes, they are new and sturdy, filling residual space with beans will result in hassle free transport.

[q="dlow"]Note that the flat-rate boxes are still available as well: $6.50 for Bx1 (code 00069), $10.50 for Bx2 (code 00076) and $13.25 for the Bx4 (code 00090). Unless you already have some, you have to buy the box as well; and you have to pay online via Click-and-Send, then take it to a post office for lodgement. But $13.25 for 15kg to Perth from the east coast, including tracking, is pretty good too :D
Link is [url]http://auspost.ebay.com.au[/url] (the front page there now talks about smaller flat-rate satchels than James discusses above, namely $6.20 for 500g and $10.55 for 3kg, plus the satchels themselves), but once you register for Click-and-Send you can access the box info too.
Regards,
David. [/q]
Has anyone here actually used 'click-and-send'? I have registered for it and found it incomprehensible.
In an email from Australia Post they actually say "We have many issues currently with Click and Send which could be causing some confusion on the website making the process tedious rather than simple."
Comments?

Being from WA I've used click and send almost exclusively (recycling old boxes are fun too)
The idea is you put in all the details online and pay for it online, print out the label and drop it off at post office.
Yea the website is a bit tedious to use but once it's figured out it's generally pretty straight forward for the flat rate box. The most annoying thing I found is that they don't keep a record of any 'purchases' so I generally save a pdf copy for references. I havn't had any complaints yet about my packages so it's ok.
But the website is useless if you want to cut queue and print off the label beforehand and pay later (anything non-flat rate), because the software between the website and post office must be incompatible or something, and they just go through the whole process again at the post office anyway. It's meant to save processing time but it took me two days last time to sort out the discrepancies.
The other thing is that the post office staffs generally had no previous experiences with click and send so that slow things down a bit, but after going to the same office a few times they generally know what to do now.

Okeydokey... I've hacked the trade code generator function into the old list only view:
:d6-2: [url=http://zincgames.com/sandpit/bgg-gl-list.php?glid=140281][COLOR=#0033FF][b][size=18]GL List Only[/size][/b][/COLOR][/url] gives a list of all items on one page along with checkboxes to quickly highlight stuff you're interested in.
In addition to doing some guesswork based on the number of words in the item's title, it will also look for a code. The code is the same format used by JeffyJeff's OLWLG (I figured there's no reason we can't have compatibility if needed), and the format is as follows:
[c]+altname+ Reality Always Needs Dimpled Yaks -altname-[/c] [i]If this was the 123rd game on the list, its code would be 0123-RANDY[/i]
Anything between the [c]+altname+[/c] and the [c]-altname-[/c] is used to generate the trade code instead of the original name. For example, last trade we had some NDS games that had no entries. This option allows them to have a meaningful name in the GL List.
[COLOR=#CC0000][b]Disclaimer: Do not take these generated codes to be the final ones! I'm putting this up for discussion as an option and they are likely to change, especially with people playing with the altnames![/b][/COLOR]
Geekmail me if anything breaks as I won't have much time to check back here on the geeklist in the next couple of days.

[q="mr_lunch"]:d6-2: [url=http://zincgames.com/sandpit/bgg-gl-list.php?glid=140281][COLOR=#0033FF][b][size=18]GL List Only[/size][/b][/COLOR][/url] gives a list of all items on one page along with checkboxes to quickly highlight stuff you're interested in.
[c]+altname+ Reality Always Needs Dimpled Yaks -altname-[/c] [i]If this was the 123rd game on the list, its code would be 0123-RANDY[/i]
Anything between the [c]+altname+[/c] and the [c]-altname-[/c] is used to generate the trade code instead of the original name. For example, last trade we had some NDS games that had no entries. This option allows them to have a meaningful name in the GL List.
[COLOR=#CC0000][b]Disclaimer: Do not take these generated codes to be the final ones! I'm putting this up for discussion as an option and they are likely to change, especially with people playing with the altnames![/b][/COLOR][/q]I like, though ultimately it is up to the organisers to accept this technique which may save them hours of work once you get the ability to post the codes onto the main geeklist.
Just think of the fun in generating all those [b]0123-RANDY[/b] codes and the like. I did notice both PitchCar Expansions ([listitem=2104235]082[/listitem] & [listitem=2104237]083[/listitem]) had the same code.

It still needs some tweaking. For example, I'm being a bit lazy in shortening words like 'A' & 'The' by doing a quick check for the word having 3 or fewer letters. This produces ugly codes like [c]0049-DXXXX[/c]... so I'll fix that if this is considered usable :)
The PitchCar naming shouldn't be too much of an issue since they still have the identifying number.

[q="The great English poet, Les Barker (who often tours Australia)"]
[u] Chronology [/u]
No, this is the very last line
I didn’t know I was doing it. I did it unthinking it for years. It isn’t until you look back, From a distance, a pattern appears
I did everything in chronological order. You don’t see at the time, you’re immersed, But all of the things, I did later in life, Were done after the things I did first.
It’s all in chronological order. It’s frustrating, I get really vexed. I’d like to do something sooner or later, But everything comes out as next
I’d like to do the next thing I do Before something that’s already done, Or maybe finish a job A week before it’s begun
Then I’d be free as the birds. Then I’d be free of this curse. And this didn’t finish the verse If this line didn’t come first?
There, I broke the bonds of time I shall treasure that brief second when For a moment my then stood alongside your now But my now was long gone with your then
I used to do things in chronological order But that’s not the case anymore Before just came after after After before before
Each moment was set by convention A link in a chain hereby broken You can now hear each word that I say But in they’re not order the spoken
Eight o’clock, Eleven, Five, Four, Nine, One, My mind is constrained by no border Seven o’clock, six, ten, three, twelve, two I count time in alphabetical order
Make April the start of your year, And Wednesday the end of your week, Listen when you want to hear, Don’t wait till somebody speaks
Don’t live your life strictly in sequence Don’t march to the chime of time’s bell Don’t wait till today to take action Make yesterday the day you rebel
Life’s fuller when time is fragmented When the sequence of history varies It’s easy to face Armageddon When it’s followed by a week in the Canaries
No more chronological order I move round my day by design This is not the last line of the poem [/q]

item.comment: Is it as good as the movie?

[q="tiggers"]Is it as good as the movie?[/q] It's an an interesting co-op heist with great components. The main problem is that the rules are awful and the small amount of text on components is in Italian -- so, it's about as good as a decent Lupin III movie that's been incredibly badly dubbed into English and then helpfully subtitled in Italian.
I'm sorry to see Amiguero let his copy go because I think it would be better on the second play and I want to try it again! :shake:
(P.S. "The" movie? Including the 20+ feature-length made-for-TV specials, there are actually around thirty Lupin movies. If you've only seen The Castle of Cagliostro and are inclined to try more, I think [url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0827737/]Lupin III: Episode 0 - First Contact[/url] is a good place to start -- a prequel about how the gang and Zenigata all meet.)

You can have a look to my session report in the following link:
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/790867/lupin-the-3rd-session-report-from-anime-fan
Ahh, bringing back some good memories here. Classic anime. I had no idea there was a game with this theme.
Do you want to play it?

The previous owner added black lines between the spaces on the sweet [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/image/160368/blood-bowl-second-edition]"astrogranite" pitch[/url].
[b]ALSO INCLUDES[/b] [thing=2286][/thing]. I can't find a list of components at all, so I'm not sure if any of the tokens it may or may not have come with are missing. There are 48 star player cards which I think is all of them.

item.objectname: Killer Bunnies and the Quest for the Magic Carrot
item.body:
Includes the yellow, red and purple boosters all conveniently packed into the base game's box.
The cards are still in very good condition but the box has some shelf wear.
We played this quite a bit but I think we've discovered all the strategy there is in this game so it's time to move on. :p

Eagle games edition. In very good condition - played a couple of times.
One does not simply walk into Bordercon, so I won't be there.

This is the original version of this game - the one with Saddam Hussein on the cover.
The box is a little beat up, but not at all bad for a 25-year-old game.
There is a minor board rip. It's there and obvious, but it is cosmetic damage only, really.
It's missing one die (a d8) - again, this is a minor issue as it still has 3 d8s anyway.
There is indeed one US Infantry piece missing, but as mentioned above, this is easily solvable.
A couple of other infantry pieces are a little 'weak in the knees'...
There is also a bag of surplus pieces for the invaders, so you have replacements if you lose something.
Bordercon? I can't handle the Bordercon! So I won't be there.

First re-print, but just the base game. Picked it up at Cancon. Played once.
I'm too cool for Bordercon.

item.comment:
A great little solo game covering the East Front in WWII, I'm surprised you're parting with it Pete.
The player controls the Axis forces trying to destroy Russia before they can build up their forces. The 'game' plays Russia, managing the retreat and eventually the Russian counter-attack (ie: the rules provide details on how the Russians retreat and attack).
Just didn't work for me. Hopefully it will work for someone else.

[q="some_guy"][q="Moose_Head"]Help me out here, what is so good about this game ?...[/q] [thing=823][/thing] is basically [thing=37111][/thing] WITHOUT the traitor. Still good, but slightly flavourless.[/q]
In my opinion it is a truly excellent introduction into cooperative gaming. It does not feature a traitor or have the game overtly try to screw you, so it is well suited to family play. It can be taught in 5 minutes and would be easily understood by children from about 8 up (and grandparents!), and it plays in less than an hour.
I agree that its simpler mechanics may not make it as enticing to "experienced" gamers, but it is always on my short-list of possible choices to induct newbies, and is a thoroughly recommended stepping stone to the more challenging implications of [thing=15062][/thing] and [thing=37111][/thing].
Well the game does overtly screw you, but what did you expect from Sauron? The ebay price is now $26.50, doesn't Randy look like a bastard! I love this game, but I already have it.

[q="Friendless"]Well the game does overtly screw you, but what did you expect from Sauron? The ebay price is now $26.50, doesn't Randy look like a bastard! I love this game, but I already have it.[/q]

item.comment: [q="Thiessi"]This game is fantastic. [/q]Agreed, from Australian designer [person=770][/person] plays best with 4p. If you impose 5 min limit for planning phase it greatly improves the game.

[q="Moose_Head"][q="Thiessi"]This game is fantastic. [/q]. If you impose 5 min limit for planning phase it greatly improves the game.[/q]
I'll have to try this. The planning phase tends to drag on, especially late at night...

[q="Moose_Head"][q="Thiessi"]This game is fantastic. [/q]Agreed, from Australian designer [person=770][/person] plays best with 4p. If you impose 5 min limit for planning phase it greatly improves the game.[/q]
I agree it is a fantastic game, the only things I don't like are the turn order and the catch up mechanics, and it bothers me enough that I'm not sure if I'll play it too much, someone else can benefit from it.

When I played it (it was in preproduction at that stage) I didn't notice any catch up mechanics. My impression (and that of a few other BGGers based on their game comments) is the opposite - that the game suffers from runaway loser problems. If bash the leader - which can be achieved in spades - is the catch up mechanic then I agree. What are the catch up mechanics that help someone who gets off to a bad start though?
EDIT: After checking I realise the French can help a player who is low on points but nothing can help a player who makes the fatal error of going for points early and loses their income. Nothing.

[q="Critical Mass"]When I played it (it was in preproduction at that stage) I didn't notice any catch up mechanics. My impression (and that of a few other BGGers based on their game comments) is the opposite - that the game suffers from runaway loser problems. If bash the leader - which can be achieved in spades - is the catch up mechanic then I agree. What are the catch up mechanics that help someone who gets off to a bad start though?
EDIT: After checking I realise the French can help a player who is low on points but nothing can help a player who makes the fatal error of going for points early and loses their income. Nothing.[/q]The bash up the leader mechanic is the flaw in the game and difficult to recover from if they time it right. The Assistance from the French, someone did suggest it was a French letter, whilst up to 25 income once only only helps when the leader is thoroughly stomped on.Sadly, I still haven't worked out how to go under the radar on this one and so I am on the receiving end.

[q="Critical Mass"]When I played it (it was in preproduction at that stage) I didn't notice any catch up mechanics. My impression (and that of a few other BGGers based on their game comments) is the opposite - that the game suffers from runaway loser problems. If bash the leader - which can be achieved in spades - is the catch up mechanic then I agree. What are the catch up mechanics that help someone who gets off to a bad start though?
EDIT: After checking I realise the French can help a player who is low on points but nothing can help a player who makes the fatal error of going for points early and loses their income. Nothing.[/q]
That's what I meant. The turn order as I remember always benefit the leader and while the French is very powerful it's a one time thing, and require a bit of forethought/planning. In fact, I won my first game by timing my French aid perfectly.
But it does have lots of interesting strategies. E.g. great theme and some great mechanics, the open information/secret bidding makes the game fun and tense which lots of opportunity for deal-making/breaking and bluffing.
